intro: Valeriana rapini, commonly known as wild cabbage or field mustard, is a biennial or annual plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes other cruciferous plants like broccoli and cauliflower. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring lobed leaves and bright yellow flowers that bloom in early summer. Its seeds are small and contain compounds that have been studied for their potential medicinal properties. Valeriana rapini is also an important plant in ecological studies due to its role in supporting pollinators and its adaptability to various soil types.
